summary: SKShaper.Shape() returns all-zero Codepoints on Android when typeface created via SKTypeface.FromStream — workaround is to use SKTypeface.FromData instead

bugSignals.workaroundSummary: Use SKTypeface.FromData(SKData.Create(stream)) instead of SKTypeface.FromStream(stream). The FromData path produces a typeface whose OpenStream data is correctly read by HarfBuzz on Android.
bugSignals.severityReason: Functional breakage of HarfBuzz shaping on Android, but a known workaround exists (FromData instead of FromStream). Does not crash — produces incorrect output (all-zero codepoints).

codeSnippets.code:
var shaper = new SKShaper(paint.Typeface);
var result = shaper.Shape("Hello world!", 10, 300, paint); // result.Codepoints are all 0
codeSnippets.context: Demonstrates Shape() returning all-zero Codepoints on Android

stepsToReproduce: Load a TTF/OTF font via SKTypeface.FromStream(stream) on Android
Create an SKShaper with the typeface
Call shaper.Shape("Hello world!", x, y, paint)
reproEvidence.environmentDetails: Android (emulator x86 and LG G4 ARMv8); works on WPF and iOS

versionAnalysis.reason: Current SKTypeface.FromStream now converts SKManagedStream to a memory stream before passing to native code (line 105-108 in SKTypeface.cs), which is functionally equivalent to the FromData workaround. The HarfBuzz version has also been updated significantly since 2018. Both changes likely resolve this issue.
versionAnalysis.migrationPath: Upgrade to latest SkiaSharp (3.x). The FromStream implementation now copies data to memory, matching the FromData workaround behavior.

fixStatus.reason: SKTypeface.FromStream now converts managed streams to memory streams (SKTypeface.cs:105-108), making it functionally equivalent to the FromData workaround. Additionally, HarfBuzz has been updated since 2018. Both changes address the likely root cause: the managed stream data not being fully materialized in memory when HarfBuzz tried to read the typeface blob on Android.

codeInvestigation.relevance: FromStream now converts SKManagedStream to memory stream (line 105-108) before passing to native code. This is functionally the same as the FromData workaround — the data is fully copied to memory. This change likely fixes the original bug.
FromData calls sk_typeface_create_from_data directly with an SKData handle. This path always worked because SKData holds a contiguous memory buffer — confirming the workaround.

SKShaper constructor calls Typeface.OpenStream() then ToHarfBuzzBlob(). If the typeface's internal stream data was incomplete (due to the old FromStream bug), HarfBuzz would receive garbled data and fail to resolve glyph codepoints.
ToHarfBuzzBlob reads the stream's memory base or copies data. If the stream asset's backing memory was invalid on Android, HarfBuzz would get bad font data, explaining the all-zero codepoints.

proposals.title: Use SKTypeface.FromData instead of FromStream
proposals.description: The original workaround found by the reporter: create SKData from the stream first, then use SKTypeface.FromData(). This forces a full memory copy of the font data.

payload.draftBody:
Thanks for the thorough investigation and the workaround using `SKTypeface.FromData()` — that was exactly the right diagnosis.

The root cause was that `SKTypeface.FromStream()` on Android didn't fully materialize the font data in memory before passing it to native Skia. HarfBuzz then received incomplete blob data and couldn't resolve glyph codepoints.

This has been addressed in current SkiaSharp — `FromStream()` now converts managed streams to memory streams internally, which is functionally the same as the `FromData()` workaround. Upgrading to the latest SkiaSharp should resolve this without any code changes.

Closing as fixed. If anyone still sees this behavior on a recent version, please open a new issue.

actions.reason: Root cause addressed by managed-to-memory stream conversion in current SKTypeface.FromStream
